document.topic_text: Game 6 has also become mental hurdle for Ducks Game 6 has also become mental hurdle for Ducks jmga April 25, 2016 News No Comments NASHVILLE, Tenn. – Here we go again. This isn’t Game 7 yet. It isn’t time to fret about the Ducks having that series-deciding game at home once again and recall the times they’ve trudged off the Honda Center ice surface in dispirited fashion wondering how and why. But what they have right in front of them is more important. Before the three Game 7 home losses that’s become the overarching definition of their most recent postseasons, there has been a Game 6 to play on the road, an initial chance to put away their opponent for good. The results became the precursor to the nightmarish Game 7s. The Ducks didn’t win in Detroit in the 2013 first round, couldn’t finish off the Kings at Staples Center in the 2014 second round and fell to eventual Stanley Cup champion Chicago in the Western Conference finals. Coach Bruce Boudreau knows the hurdle – mental and physical – that his team has to clear. He mildly chided a reporter on Sunday for bringing up the past after their Game 5 win over Nashville. But to get where they want to go, their Game 6 troubles are pertinent and something the Ducks have to overcome. “Well, there’s all the old clichés,” Boudreau said. “I don’t think it’s any secret. You want to win Game 6 because you don’t want to have a Game 7.
